questions.question: A surgeon is performing an axillary dissection for breast cancer and must be cautious not to damage structures piercing the clavipectoral fascia. Which of the following statements about these structures is TRUE? draining into the axillary vein. acromial, and clavicular branches. muscle after piercing the pectoralis major. central axillary lymph nodes.

options.A: The cephalic vein pierces the clavipectoral fascia and runs through the deltopectoral groove before
options.B: The thoracoacromial artery pierces the clavipectoral fascia and divides into pectoral, deltoid,
options.C: Lateral pectoral nerve passes through the clavipectoral fascia and innervates the pectoralis minor
options.D: Lymphatic vessels draining the lateral breast region pierce the clavipectoral fascia and drain into the

questions.explanation: deltopectoral groove before draining into the axillary vein. Correct Answer: A) The cephalic vein pierces the clavipectoral fascia and runs through the deltopectoral groove before draining into the axillary vein. Explanation: The cephalic vein courses in the deltopectoral groove , then pierces the clavipectoral fascia to drain into the axillary vein . It is a reliable landmark during axillary dissections and must be preserved or ligated with care. Clavipectoral Fascia and Piercing Structures: Feature Description Location Lies deep to pectoralis major, extends from clavicle to axillary fascia Pierced by Cephalic vein Thoracoacromial artery and its branches Lateral pectoral nerve Lymphatics from lateral breast Clinical relevance During axillary dissection, these structures must be protected Feature Details Cephalic vein (Option A) Arises from dorsal venous network of the hand Runs in deltopectoral groove with deltoid branch of thoracoacromial artery Pierces clavipectoral fascia to drain into axillary vein Thoracoacromial artery (Option B) Branch of second part of axillary artery Pierces clavipectoral fascia Gives off pectoral, deltoid, clavicular, acromial branches (no 'axillary' branch) Lateral pectoral nerve (Option C) Arises from lateral cord of brachial plexus Pierces clavipectoral fascia near thoracoacromial artery Passes medial to pectoralis minor Innervates pectoralis major only Lymphatics (Option D) Drain lateral breast and pectoral region Pierce clavipectoral fascia to reach apical axillary lymph nodes , not central nodes Suspensory ligament of axilla Inferior extension of clavipectoral fascia Anchors axillary fascia to maintain axillary fossa concavity

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the rotator cuff muscles? collectively aid in shoulder abduction and external rotation.

options.A: The rotator cuff includes the Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Subscapularis, and Teres major, which
options.B: The Subscapularis is the only rotator cuff muscle involved in internal rotation of the humerus.
options.C: The Infraspinatus and Teres minor are responsible for medial rotation of the shoulder joint.
options.D: The rotator cuff muscles are primarily located in the anterior aspect of the shoulder joint

questions.explanation: the humerus. the humerus. Explanation: Rotator Cuff Muscles: Muscle (Tendon) Action Nerve Supply Supraspinatus Initiates abduction of the shoulder Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6) Infraspinatus External( lateral)rotation of the shoulder Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6) Teres minor External(lateral) rotation of the shoulder Axillary nerve (C5,C6) Subscapularis Internal (medial) rotation of the shoulder Upper and lower subscapular nerves (C5,C6,C7) The rotator cuff is composed of the Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Subscapularis, and Teres minor, not Teres major (Option A). The Infraspinatus and Teres minor are involved in external (lateral) rotation, not medial rotation. (Option C) The rotator cuff muscles are located primarily around the shoulder joint, with some being posterior (e.g., Infraspinatus, Teres minor) and one anterior (Subscapularis) (Option D). Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 78

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct pairing of shoulder movement and the muscle involved?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Adduction-pectoralis major Explanation: Fig: Shoulder Movements Movement of the shoulder joint Muscle(s) Involved Other movements Adduction Pectoralis major (Option A) Teres major (Option C) Latissimus dorsi Coracobrachialis Short head of biceps brachii Long head of triceps brachii Medial rotation of scapula Abduction Supraspinatus (0-15) (Option D) Deltoid (15-90) Serratus anterior (90°–180°) (Option B) Upper and lower fibers of trapezius (90°–180°) Humerus elevation Clavicle axial rotation AC joint movement Lateral rotation of scapula Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 162

questions.question: Match the wall of the axilla with the structure forming it: Wall Structure forming 3. Clavipectoral fascia d. Lateral wall 4. Subscapularis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) a3,b4,c1,d2 Explanation: Wall of axilla Contributing structure Anterior Wall Pectoralis major Clavipectoral fascia Pectoralis minor Posterior Wall Subscapularis Teres major Latissimus dorsi Medial Wall Upper four ribs with intercostal muscles Upper part of serratus anterior Lateral Wall Bicipital groove of humerus Coracobrachialis Short head of biceps brachii Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 52-53

questions.question: Which of the following fasciae is the axillary sheath derived from?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Deep cervical fascia Explanation: The axillary sheath is derived from the prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia. Apex/Cervicoaxillary Canal: Directed upwards and medially towards the root of the neck Axillary artery, axillary vein, and brachial plexus enter the axilla through this canal Axillary vessels and cords of the brachial plexus are in the axillary sheath which is derived from the prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia Boundaries of Cervicoaxillary Canal: Anteriorly Posterior surface of the clavicle Posteriorly Superior border of the scapula and medial aspect of the coracoid process Medially Outer border of the first rib Contents of the Axilla: Axillary artery and its branches Axillary vein and its tributaries Infraclavicular part of the brachial plexus Five groups of axillary lymph nodes and the associated lymphatics The long thoracic and intercostobrachial nerves Axillary fat and areolar tissue in which the other contents are embedded Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 51-53

questions.question: A 35-year-old construction worker falls from a ladder and lands on his outstretched hand, resulting in a clavicular fracture as shown in the X- Ray given below. Which ligament plays a crucial role in stabilizing the medial end of the clavicle to the first rib, preventing excessive elevation of the clavicle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Costoclavicular ligament Explanation: Costoclavicular ligament anchors the medial end of the clavicle to the first rib and acts as a strong stabilizer that limits excessive elevation of the clavicle . It is critical in maintaining clavicular positioning , particularly during weight-bearing activities involving the upper limb. The clavicle is often fractured by an indirect fall on an outstretched hand . The most common fracture site is at the junction of its two curvatures, the weakest point . The lateral fragment is displaced downward due to the weight of the limb, as the trapezius muscle cannot fully support it. Location on Clavicle Attachment Lateral End (Acromial end) Joint capsule of the acromioclavicular joint Medial End (Sternal end) Fibrous capsule of sternoclavicular joint (all around) Articular disc (posterosuperiorly) Interclavicular ligament (superiorly) Lateral One-Third of Shaft Anterior border: Origin of deltoid muscle Posterior border: Insertion of trapezius muscle Conoid tubercle and trapezoid ridge: Attachment to the conoid and trapezoid parts of coracoclavicular ligament Medial Two-Thirds of Shaft Anterior surface: Origin of pectoralis major Rough superior surface: Origin of clavicular head of sternocleidomastoid Oval impression (inferior surface, medial end) : Attachment of costoclavicular ligament Subclavian groove: Insertion of subclavius muscle , margins give attachment to clavipectoral fascia Posterior surface (near medial end) : Origin of sternohyoid muscle Coracoclavicular ligament (Option A) primarily stabilizes the lateral end of the clavicle by connecting it to the coracoid process of the scapula, providing support for the acromioclavicular joint . Weight transmission from upper limb to axial skeleton.

questions.question: A 45-year-old painter presents with shoulder pain and weakness, particularly when raising his arm. He reports difficulty lifting objects overhead. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the shoulder and weakness in initiating arm abduction. Which rotator cuff muscle is most likely injured?
questions.explanation: like painting. Rotator Cuff Muscles Muscles and muscle action The rotator cuff consists of four muscles: Supraspinatus: Located above the scapular spine, it aids in arm abduction and is the most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle. (Option C) Infraspinatus: Below the scapular spine, it helps with lateral arm rotation and shoulder stabilization. (Option A ruled out) Teres Minor: Works with the infraspinatus in lateral rotation and stabilizing the shoulder. (Option B ruled out) Subscapularis: On the front of the scapula, it is responsible for medial arm rotation and is the only rotator cuff muscle that doesn’t attach to the greater tubercle of the humerus and forgotten tendon. (Option D ruled out) Musculotendinous Cuff: The tendons of these muscles form the rotator cuff , which supports and stabilizes the shoulder joint during movement. Functions Stabilize the shoulder. Rotate the arm (medially and laterally). Assist with arm abduction. Control arm movement, especially overhead. Clinical Relevance Rotator cuff tears: Resulting in pain, weakness, and limited movement. Subacromial bursitis: Inflammation causing shoulder pain and stiffness. Axillary nerve injury: Can weaken shoulder abduction by affecting the deltoid muscle. Muscle (Tendon) Action Nerve supply Supraspinatus Initiates abduction of the shoulder Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6) Infraspinatus External and lateral rotation of the shoulder Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6) Teres minor External and lateral rotation of the shoulder Axillary nerve (C5,C6) Subscapularis Internal and medial rotation of the shoulder Upper and lower subscapular nerves (C5,C6,C7)

questions.question: A 55 year old man, a former construction worker, presents with shoulder pain and limited range of motion. His examination finding is shown below in the image and there is tenderness over the lateral aspect of his ribcage. Which muscle is most likely compromised in function, and what nerve injury could be contributing to his condition?

options.A: Pectoralis Major; Medial pectoral nerve injury
options.B: Pectoralis Minor; Lateral pectoral nerve injury
options.D: Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury

questions.explanation: Correct Answer :D) Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury Explanation: Serratus Anterior is essential for stabilizing the scapula and upward rotation. Winging indicates weakness due to long thoracic nerve injury , common in repetitive overhead activities. Muscles of the Anterior Axioappendicular Region Muscle Origin Insertion Nerve Supply Actions Pectoralis Major (Option A ruled out) Anterior surface of the medial two-thirds of the clavicle Front of the manubrium and sternum up to the 6th costal cartilages Second to sixth costal cartilages and sternal end of the 6th rib Aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle Lateral lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus (via bilaminar tendon) Medial and lateral pectoral nerves Adducts and medially rotates the arm Flexes the arm (clavicular part) Extends the flexed arm against resistance (sternocostal part) Pectoralis Minor (Option B ruled out) 3rd, 4th, and 5th ribs near the costochondral junction Medial border and upper surface of the coracoid process Medial and lateral pectoral nerves Protracts the scapula Lowers the point of the shoulder Subclavius (Option C ruled out) First rib at the costochondral junction Subclavian groove on the middle third of the clavicle Nerve to subclavius (from upper trunk of brachial plexus) Stabilizes the clavicle during shoulder movements Protects axillary vessels and brachial plexus Serratus Anterior (Option D) Eight digitations from the upper 8 ribs and fascia over the intercostal muscles Costal surface of the medial border of the scapula Long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7) Protracts scapula Rotates scapula upward for arm abduction beyond 90 degrees Stabilizes the scapula during weight-bearing activities Assists in forced inspiration

questions.question: A 35-year-old swimmer presents with weakness during arm extension and difficulty pulling objects toward himself. He also reports pain during forceful expiration, such as coughing or sneezing. Which muscle is most likely involved, and what is its nerve supply?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Latissimus Dorsi; Thoracodorsal nerve Explanation : Latissimus Dorsi is involved in arm extension, adduction, medial rotation and forceful expiration (such as coughing or sneezing); innervated by the thoracodorsal nerve. Muscles of the posterior Axioappendicular Region Muscle Origin Insertion Nerve Supply Actions Trapezius (Option A ruled out) Medial one-third of the superior nuchal line of the skull External occipital protuberance Ligamentum nuchae Spinous processes of C7 to T12 vertebrae Corresponding supraspinous ligaments Upper fibers: Posterior border of the lateral one-third of the clavicle Middle fibers: Medial margin of the acromion and upper lip of the spine of the scapula Lower fibers: Apex of a triangular area at the medial end of the spine of the scapula (intervening bursa) Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) Proprioceptive fibers from C3 and C4. Upper fibers: Elevate the scapula (shoulder shrugging), extend the neck (bilaterally) Middle fibers: Retract the scapula Lower fibers: Rotate the scapula upward, aiding arm abduction beyond 90 degrees Trapezius with rhomboids: Retract scapula and tilt glenoid inferiorly. Trapezius with serratus anterior: Overhead abduction and tilt glenoid superiorly. All fibers together: Stabilize the scapula during arm movements Latissimus Dorsi (Option B) Posterior one-third of the outer lip of the iliac crest Posterior layer of lumbar fascia (connecting to lumbar and sacral spines) Spinous processes of T7 to T12 Lower four ribs Inferior angle of the scapula Fibers twist to insert into the floor of the intertubercular sulcus of the humerus, wrapping around the lower border of the teres major. Thoracodorsal nerve (C6, C7, C8). Extends, adducts, and medially rotates the arm (e.g., swimming, climbing) Assists in forceful expiration (e.g., coughing, sneezing) Levator Scapulae (Option D ruled out) Transverse processes of C1 to C4 vertebrae Superior angle and upper part of the medial border of the scapula Dorsal scapular nerve (C5) and branches from C3 and C4 Elevates and stabilizes the scapula during arm movements. Rhomboid Minor (Option C ruled out) Lower part of ligamentum nuchae and spinous processes of C7 and T1 Medial border of the scapula at the base of the triangular area at the root of the spine. Dorsal scapular nerve (C5) Retracts and stabilizes the scapula. Rhomboid Major Spinous processes of T2 to T5 and supraspinous ligaments Medial border of the scapula, below the root of the spine Dorsal scapular nerve (C5) Retracts and stabilizes the scapula.

questions.question: A 60-year-old female patient presents to the ED with a tension pneumothorax. The physician decides to perform a chest drain insertion to relieve the pressure. As the physician prepares for the procedure, they review the anatomical landmarks to ensure they insert the drain safely. Which muscle defines the posterior boundary of the Triangle of Safety, ensuring that the physician avoids vital structures during the chest drain insertion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Latissimus dorsi Explanation: The lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle forms the posterior boundary of the Triangle of Safety for ICD insertion. Triangle of Safety for Intercostal Chest Drain (ICD) insertion: Anatomical area on the lateral chest wall where it is considered safest to insert a chest drain. Boundaries of the triangle: Anteriorly Lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle. Posteriorly Lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle. Inferiorly A horizontal line at the level of the 5th intercostal space (usually aligned with the nipple in males). Superiorly Base of the axilla(armpit). This area minimizes the risk of injury to vital structures such as nerves, blood vessels, and the lung itself. The drain is typically inserted in the 4th or 5th intercostal space along the mid-axillary line.

questions.question: Which muscle forms the medial border of the Triangle of Auscultation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Trapezius Explanation: The medial border of the Triangle of Auscultation is formed by the lateral edge of the trapezius muscle. Triangle of Auscultation: Anatomical Location: Located on the posterior thorax, specifically on the back, just below the scapula. Boundaries : Medial Border Lateral border of the trapezius muscle. Lateral Border Medial border of the scapula. Inferior Border Superior border of the latissimus dorsi muscle. Anterior or floor Rhomboid major, 6th and 7th ribs. Clinical Significance: This area is important for auscultating lung sounds because it is relatively free from muscle and bone interference. It allows for clearer sounds of breath , particularly in patients with respiratory issues. Positioning : To enhance the visibility and accessibility of the triangle, patients are often instructed to lean forward and cross their arms, which brings the scapulae apart and exposes this area. Reference: Triangle of auscultation

questions.question: Which of the following nerves is responsible for winging of scapula?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Long thoracic nerve Explanation: Winging of the scapula occurs due to paralysis or weakness of the serratus anterior muscle , which is innervated by the long thoracic nerve. The serratus anterior muscle normally holds the scapula against the thoracic wall. Damage to the long thoracic nerve results in a characteristic “winged” appearance of the scapula, especially when the patient pushes against a wall. Dorsal scapular nerve (Option A): Innervates the rhomboid major and minor and levator scapulae, which retract and elevate the scapula. Injury to this nerve does not cause winging of the scapula. Spinal accessory nerve (Option B): Innervates the trapezius muscle, which elevates and rotates the scapula. Damage leads to shoulder drooping and difficulty elevating the arm but does not cause scapular winging. Suprascapular nerve (Option D): Innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, which assist in shoulder abduction and external rotation. Injury affects shoulder movement, not scapular positioning. Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 45,46,48,49

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the muscles involved in abduction of shoulder?

options.A: Supraspinatous is involved in initiation of abduction.
options.B: Deltoid is responsible for 0-15 degree abduction.
options.C: Supraspinatous is responsible for 15-90 degree abduction.
options.D: Infraspinatous is responsible for 0-15 degree abduction.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A)Supraspinatous is involved in initiation of abduction. Explanation: Muscles Involved in Shoulder Abduction: Shoulder abduction Supraspinatus (0-15) Deltoid (15-90) Serratus anterior (90°-180°) Upper and lower fibers of trapezius (90°-180°) Infraspinatus is not involved in abduction but rather in external rotation of the arm (Option D) The supraspinatus only initiates abduction (0-15°). The deltoid is the primary muscle responsible for abduction from 15-90° (Option B and C ). Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 162
